awd_titl_txt: Women in Cognitive Science:  International Collaboration, Scientific Advancement, Workplace Culture
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of Women in Cognitive Science is to improve the visibility of women in the field and to create an environment that would invite discussion of the issues that all scientists, but women in particular, may be required to negotiate in the trajectory of creating and sustaining a successful career. Several workshops are designed for women in cognitive science, especially women in the early stages of their academic career. The workshops focus on developing international collaborations, negotiating challenges to scientific advancement, and successfully navigating the workplace culture. Workshops will take place at meetings of the Psychonomic Society, the Cognitive Science Society, and the Association for Psychological Sciences. The workshops will take the form of public forums with invited speaker-panelists to initiate discussion about best practices for the professional advancement of women in cognitive science at the individual and institutional level. These workshops will be live-streamed to increase exposure, and will also feature "speed-mentoring" for personalized assistance to young faculty. By partnering with the above-mentioned established societies, the workshops will maximize the outreach potential to a group that continues to be underrepresented in senior academic positions in the cognitive sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant accomplished three goals to advance women in cognitive science – workshops, speed mentoring, and awards. 

Workshops-

We organized workshops at professional meetings on three themes, featuring keynote speakers and panel discussions: 1.  Developing international collaborations; 2.  Negotiating challenges to scientific advancement; and 3.  Workplace culture. Workshops took place at the meetings of the Psychonomic Society (2018- New Orleans, LA, USA; 2019; Montreal, Canada; 2020–Virtual). An innovation in 2018 was to present the workshop livestreamed, increasing participation and broader impact.

The broader impact of WiCS was advanced by workshops at other meetings, including Association for Psychological Science (APS, San Francisco, CA, USA, May, 2018), International Convention of Psychological Science (ICPS; Paris, France, March, 2019), International Meeting of the Psychonomic Society (Amsterdam, the Netherlands, May, 2018); Society for Applied Research in Memory and Cognition (SARMAC, Cape Cod, MA, May, 2019), Cognitive Science Society (CSS, Montreal, Canada, July, 2019), WiCS affiliated meetings (e.g., FoVEA at Vision Science Society; 2018, 2019; St. Pete Beach, Florida) and a panel at École Normale Supérieure (Paris, France, March 2019).  

Through the pandemic, WiCS continued active engagement with WiCS-Canada and WiCS-Europe. In 2020, WiCS Canada led the workshop at the Virtual CSS meeting. In 2021, WiCS and WiCS-Europe co-hosted a workshop at SARMAC Virtual (July 21-23, 2021) in different time slots to enable global attendance.

WiCS celebrated its 20th anniversary during the pandemic (2020). A virtual workshop was organized at the Psychonomic Society’s (PS) meeting, featuring a keynote by Virginia Valian, the speaker at the first WiCS meeting in 2001. A panel included remarks by key contributors who worked to advance WiCS over the past 20 years and by the new leaders of WiCS (now WiCS+; https://www.womenincogsci.org/) who have taken helm since 2020. The new leaders, led by Kate Arrington, outlined their vision in a feature titled, “Future of WiCS: Opportunities in a New Era”, to engage and advance a larger range of women cognitive scientists both nationally and internationally.

During the 2020 Virtual PS meeting, WiCS reached a live audience of over 500 attendees, more than double the audience in the past. Our partnership with the PS enabled access to live streaming of the workshop and intimate virtual spaces for discussion and mentoring. Despite the virtual platform, this workshop was a resounding success in celebrating the past, infusing optimism about the future, and sustaining the growing community. 

Speed mentoring sessions-

Established in 2015, speed mentoring sessions have taken place after WiCS workshops. They were held at APS (May 2018), ICPS (March 2019), SARMAC (May 2019), and PS (November 2018, 2019, 2020). Mentors and mentees who volunteered were paired up by the organizers ahead of the meeting.  Each mentoring session lasted no longer than 15-20 minutes and consisted of informal discussion about questions that mentees sent to mentors in advance. The feedback on these events has been uniformly positive and the mentoring events have grown (46 pairs of mentors and mentees met in 2020). The speed mentoring sessions promoted intellectual merit through discussions between mentors and mentees about matters of science and broader impact was facilitated through discussions of professional development. 

Two award mechanisms-

1. Travel and networking awards for junior scientists: WiCS continued the past awards program. These awards targeted early career women at the level of graduate student, postdoc, or junior faculty member, to support travel to a professional meeting and/or to a senior mentor’s laboratory to develop collaborations and/or gain complementary training. This mechanism supported travel and networking through the no-cost extension period. During the pandemic, research, teaching, and most aspects of the careers of our community shifted online. The new remote work environments limited opportunities for face-to-face networking, but also greatly expanded online engagement and inclusion of individuals who might not be otherwise able to participate. WiCS adapted to these changes and modified the awards to networking only, awarding several smaller awards ($500 each) to a larger number of junior scientists. Starting in 2022, in-person professional activities resumed, and WiCS reinstated the larger awards to the full, pre-pandemic amounts ($1000 each). This grant supported a total of 19 WiCS awards for junior scientists.

The intellectual merit of the work supported by this grant was realized in the scientific relationships junior scientists forged with established scientists. A notable broader impact created by the NSF-supported awards has been the sponsorship of additional awards to junior scientists by the American Psychological Association and the Psychonomic Society.  

2. Leadership Awards: In 2018, Leadership Awards replaced the previous Mentorship Award with the goal to recognize initiatives individuals have taken beyond their own labs to benefit women in cognitive science.  WiCS also conferred four Honorary Leadership Awards to recognize scientists who have provided exceptional leadership to support and advance women in cognitive science.  This grant funded eight WiCS leadership awards.
